Your task is to write a Related Works section for an academic paper given the paper's abstract. Your response should provide the Related Works section and references. Only include references from arXiv that are published before 2025-06-03T13:06:19+00:00. Mention them in a separate, numbered reference list at the end and use the reference numbers to provide in-line citations in the Related Works section for all claims referring to a source (e.g., description of source [3]. Further details [6][7][8][9][10].) Each in-line citation must consist of a single reference number within a pair of brackets. Do not use any other citation format. Do not exceed 600 words for the related works section. Here is the paper abstract:
Economic inequality is a global challenge, intensifying disparities in
education, healthcare, and social stability. Traditional systems like the U.S.
federal income tax reduce inequality but lack adaptability. Although models
like the Saez Optimal Taxation adjust dynamically, they fail to address
taxpayer heterogeneity and irrational behavior. This study introduces TaxAgent,
a novel integration of large language models (LLMs) with agent-based modeling
(ABM) to design adaptive tax policies. In our macroeconomic simulation,
heterogeneous H-Agents (households) simulate real-world taxpayer behaviors
while the TaxAgent (government) utilizes LLMs to iteratively optimize tax
rates, balancing equity and productivity. Benchmarked against Saez Optimal
Taxation, U.S. federal income taxes, and free markets, TaxAgent achieves
superior equity-efficiency trade-offs. This research offers a novel taxation
solution and a scalable, data-driven framework for fiscal policy evaluation..

introduction:
## Related Works

Economic inequality and the design of effective tax policies have been central topics in economics, with a rich literature spanning theoretical, computational, and empirical approaches. Traditional tax systems, such as the U.S. federal income tax, have long been used to mitigate inequality, but their static nature and limited adaptability have prompted the development of more dynamic frameworks and computational models to better address the complexities of real-world economies.

### Optimal Taxation and Its Limitations

The foundational work on optimal taxation, notably the Mirrlees model, has inspired extensive research into tax schedules that maximize social welfare. However, it has been shown that the Mirrlees paradigm, which focuses on maximizing total utility, often fails to produce progressive tax schedules and may even assign minimal tax rates to higher-income groups, contradicting the ethical and practical expectations in developed economies. Recent work has proposed augmenting the objective function with measures such as the standard deviation of utility to better capture equity considerations and yield more interpretable optimality criteria for income tax design \[[Vassili N. Kolokoltsov' 2024-08-10](http://arxiv.org/abs/2408.14476v1)\].

The Saez Optimal Taxation framework is a prominent example of a dynamic approach that seeks to balance equity and productivity by adjusting tax rates in response to economic conditions. While influential, such models typically assume rational, homogeneous agents and do not fully account for the heterogeneity and bounded rationality observed in real-world taxpayer behavior \[[Stephan Zheng' 2020-04-28](http://arxiv.org/abs/2004.13332v1)\]\[[Vassili N. Kolokoltsov' 2024-08-10](http://arxiv.org/abs/2408.14476v1)\]. This gap has motivated the exploration of more flexible and data-driven approaches.

### Agent-Based and Computational Economic Models

Agent-based modeling (ABM) has emerged as a powerful tool for simulating complex economic systems with heterogeneous agents. ABMs allow for the explicit modeling of diverse behaviors, interactions, and adaptation, making them well-suited for studying the emergence and effects of informal economic activity, tax evasion, and redistribution policies \[[Teddy Lazebnik' 2025-01-30](http://arxiv.org/abs/2501.18177v1)\]\[[Iago Nascimento Barros' 2025-01-15](http://arxiv.org/abs/2501.08573v1)\]\[[Lennart Fernandes' 2020-03-04](http://arxiv.org/abs/2003.04129v1)\]\[[Maria Letizia Bertotti' 2014-05-29](http://arxiv.org/abs/1407.3749v2)\]. For instance, recent studies have used ABMs powered by large language models (LLMs) and deep reinforcement learning to simulate the organic emergence of tax evasion and informal economies, highlighting the roles of personality traits, external narratives, enforcement probabilities, and public goods provision in shaping compliance behavior \[[Teddy Lazebnik' 2025-01-30](http://arxiv.org/abs/2501.18177v1)\]. These models demonstrate that neither efficient public goods provision nor robust enforcement alone is sufficient to curtail informal activity; both are necessary and complementary.

Other agent-based studies have focused on the effects of non-uniform income redistribution and tax evasion on wealth distribution, finding that well-designed redistribution policies and strict control of tax planning are essential for promoting economic equality and sustainability \[[Iago Nascimento Barros' 2025-01-15](http://arxiv.org/abs/2501.08573v1)\]. Kinetic and micro-to-macro models have also been employed to analyze
